niftoolsxml.basic: A boolean; 32-bit from 4.0.0.2, and 8-bit from 4.1.0.1 on.
A 16-bit (signed?) integer, which is used in the header to refer to a particular object type in a object type string array. The upper bit appears to be a flag used for PhysX block types.

A 32-bit integer that stores the version in hexadecimal format with each byte representing a number in the version string.
Some widely-used versions and their hex representation: 4.0.0.2: 0x04000002 4.1.0.12: 0x0401000C 4.2.0.2: 0x04020002 4.2.1.0: 0x04020100 4.2.2.0: 0x04020200 10.0.1.0: 0x0A000100 10.1.0.0: 0x0A010000 10.2.0.0: 0x0A020000 20.0.0.4: 0x14000004 20.0.0.5: 0x14000005
A 16-bit integer, used for bit flags. Function varies by object type.

A variable length string that ends with a newline character (0x0A). The string starts as follows depending on the version:
Version <= 10.0.1.0: 'NetImmerse File Format' Version >= 10.1.0.0: 'Gamebryo File Format'
A variable length string that ends with a newline character (0x0A).
A signed 32-bit integer, referring to a object before this one in the hierarchy. Examples: Bones, gravity objects.
A signed 32-bit integer, used to refer to another object; -1 means no reference. These should always point down the hierarchy. Other types are used for indexes that point to objects higher up.
A 32-bit unsigned integer, used to refer to strings in a NiStringPalette.
A 32-bit unsigned integer, used to refer to strings in the header.
niftoolsxml.enum: An unsigned 32-bit integer, describing how transparency is handled in a texture. No alpha blending; the texture is fully opaque. Texture is either fully transparent or fully opaque. There are no partially transparent areas. Full range of alpha values can be used from fully transparent to fully opaque including all partially transparent values in between. Use default setting.

An unsigned 32-bit integer, describing the apply mode of a texture. Replaces existing color For placing images on the object like stickers. Modulates existing color. (Default) PS2 Only. Function Unknown. Parallax Flag in some Oblivion meshes.

The type of texture. The basic texture used by most meshes. Used to darken the model with false lighting. Combined with base map for added detail. Usually tiled over the mesh many times for close-up view. Allows the specularity (glossyness) of an object to differ across its surface. Creates a glowing effect. Basically an incandescence map. Used to make the object appear to have more detail than it really does. Used to make the object appear to have more detail than it really does. Unknown map. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers. For placing images on the object like stickers.

The type of animation interpolation (blending) that will be used on the associated key frames. Use linear interpolation. Use quadratic interpolation. Forward and back tangents will be stored. Use Tension Bias Continuity interpolation. Tension, bias, and continuity will be stored. For use only with rotation data. Separate X, Y, and Z keys will be stored instead of using quaternions. Step function. Used for visibility keys in NiBoolData.
An unsigned 32-bit integer, describing how vertex colors influence lighting. Emissive. Emissive + Ambient + Diffuse. (Default)

A material, used by havok shape objects. Stone Cloth Dirt Glass Grass Metal Organic Skin Water Wood Heavy Stone Heavy Metal Heavy Wood Chain Snow Stone Stairs Cloth Stairs Dirt Stairs Glass Stairs Grass Stairs Metal Stairs Organic Stairs Skin Stairs Water Stairs Wood Stairs Heavy Stone Stairs Heavy Metal Stairs Heavy Wood Stairs Chain Stairs Snow Stairs Elevator Rubber

A byte describing if MOPP Data is organized into chunks (PS3) or not (PC) Organized in chunks for PS3. Not organized in chunks for PC. (Default) Build type not set yet.
An unsigned 32-bit integer, describing how mipmaps are handled in a texture. Texture does not use mip maps. Texture uses mip maps. Use default setting.

Specifies the pixel format used by the NiPixelData object to store a texture. 24-bit color: uses 8 bit to store each red, blue, and green component. 32-bit color with alpha: uses 8 bits to store each red, blue, green, and alpha component. 8-bit palette index: uses 8 bits to store an index into the palette stored in a NiPalette object. DXT1 compressed texture. DXT5 compressed texture. DXT5 compressed texture. It is not clear what the difference is with PX_FMT_DXT5.

An unsigned 32-bit integer, describing the color depth of a texture. Texture is in 8-bit paletized format. Texture is in 16-bit high color format. Texture is in 32-bit true color format. Texture is compressed. Texture is a grayscale bump map. Texture is in 4-bit paletized format. Use default setting.

Specifies the availiable texture clamp modes. That is, the behavior of pixels outside the range of the texture. Clamp in both directions. Clamp in the S(U) direction but wrap in the T(V) direction. Wrap in the S(U) direction but clamp in the T(V) direction. Wrap in both directions.

Specifies the availiable texture filter modes. That is, the way pixels within a texture are blended together when textures are displayed on the screen at a size other than their original dimentions. Simply uses the nearest pixel. Very grainy. Uses bilinear filtering. Uses trilinear filtering. Uses the nearest pixel from the mipmap that is closest to the display size. Blends the two mipmaps closest to the display size linearly, and then uses the nearest pixel from the result. Uses the closest mipmap to the display size and then uses bilinear filtering on the pixels.
An unsigned 32-bit integer, which describes how to apply vertex colors. Source Ignore. Source Emissive. Source Ambient/Diffuse. (Default)
The animation cyle behavior. Loop Reverse Clamp
The force field's type. Wind (fixed direction) Point (fixed origin)

Determines the way the billboard will react to the camera. The billboard will always face the camera. The billboard will only rotate around the up axis. Rigid Face Camera. Always Face Center. Rigid Face Center. The billboard will only rotate around the up axis (same as ROTATE_ABOUT_UP?).

This enum contains the options for doing stencil buffer tests. Test will allways return false. Nothing is drawn at all. The test will only succeed if the pixel is nearer than the previous pixel. Test will only succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is equal to the value of the previous drawn pixel. Test will succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is smaller than or equal to the value in the Stencil Buffer. Opposite of TEST_LESS. Test will succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is NOT equal to the value of the previously drawn pixel. Opposite of TEST_LESS_EQUAL. Test will allways succeed. The Stencil Buffer value is ignored.

This enum contains the options for doing z buffer tests. Test will allways succeed. The Z Buffer value is ignored. The test will only succeed if the pixel is nearer than the previous pixel. Test will only succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is equal to the value of the previous drawn pixel. Test will succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is smaller than or equal to the value in the Z Buffer. Opposite of TEST_LESS. Test will succeed if the z value of the pixel to be drawn is NOT equal to the value of the previously drawn pixel. Opposite of TEST_LESS_EQUAL. Test will allways return false. Nothing is drawn at all.
This enum defines the various actions used in conjunction with the stencil buffer. For a detailed description of the individual options please refer to the OpenGL docs.

This enum lists the different face culling options. use application defaults? Draw counter clock wise faces, cull clock wise faces. This is the default for most (all?) Nif Games so far. Draw clock wise faces, cull counter clock wise faces. This will flip all the faces. Draw double sided faces.

The motion system. 4 (Box) is used for everything movable. 7 (Keyframed) is used on statics and animated stuff.
Invalid A fully-simulated, movable rigid body. At construction time the engine checks the input inertia and selects MO_SYS_SPHERE_INERTIA or MO_SYS_BOX_INERTIA as appropriate. Simulation is performed using a sphere inertia tensor. This is the same as MO_SYS_SPHERE_INERTIA, except that simulation of the rigid body is "softened". Simulation is performed using a box inertia tensor. This is the same as MO_SYS_BOX_INERTIA, except that simulation of the rigid body is "softened". Simulation is not performed as a normal rigid body. The keyframed rigid body has an infinite mass when viewed by the rest of the system. (used for creatures) This motion type is used for the static elements of a game scene, e.g. the landscape. Faster than MO_SYS_KEYFRAMED at velocity 0. (used for weapons) A box inertia motion which is optimized for thin boxes and has less stability problems A specialized motion used for character controllers

enum.name: DeactivatorType
enum.option: This will force the rigid body to never deactivate.
Tells Havok to use a spatial deactivation scheme. This makes use of high and low frequencies of positional motion to determine when deactivation should occur.

niftoolsxml.enum: A list of possible solver deactivation settings. This value defines how the solver deactivates objects. The solver works on a per object basis. Note: Solver deactivation does not save CPU, but reduces creeping of movable objects in a pile quite dramatically. Invalid No solver deactivation Very conservative deactivation, typically no visible artifacts. Normal deactivation, no serious visible artifacts in most cases Fast deactivation, visible artifacts Very fast deactivation, visible artifacts

The motion type. Determines quality of motion? Automatically assigned to MO_QUAL_FIXED, MO_QUAL_KEYFRAMED or MO_QUAL_DEBRIS Use this for fixed bodies. Use this for moving objects with infinite mass. Use this for all your debris objects Use this for moving bodies, which should not leave the world. Use this for all objects, which you cannot afford to tunnel through the world at all Use this for very fast objects For user. Use this for rigid body character controllers
Use this for moving objects with infinite mass which should report contact points and Toi-collisions against all other bodies, including other fixed and keyframed bodies.
The type of force? May be more valid values.

Determines how a NiTextureTransformController animates the UV coordinates. Means this controller moves the U texture cooridnates. Means this controller moves the V texture cooridnates. Means this controller roates the UV texture cooridnates. Means this controller scales the U texture cooridnates. Means this controller scales the V texture cooridnates.
Determines decay function. Used by NiPSysBombModifier. No decay. Linear decay. Exponential decay.
Determines symetry type used by NiPSysBombModifier. Spherical Symmetry. Cylindrical Symmetry. Planar Symmetry.

Controls the way the a particle mesh emitter determines the starting speed and direction of the particles that are emitted. Uses the normals of the meshes to determine staring velocity. Starts particles with a random velocity. Uses the emission axis to determine initial particle direction?

Controls which parts of the mesh that the particles are emitted from. Emit particles from the vertices of the mesh. Emit particles from the center of the faces of the mesh. Emit particles from the center of the edges of the mesh. Perhaps randomly emit particles from anywhere on the faces of the mesh? Perhaps randomly emit particles from anywhere on the edges of the mesh?

The type of information that's store in a texture used by a NiTextureEffect. Apply a projected light texture. Apply a projected shaddow texture. Apply an environment map texture. Apply a fog map texture.
Determines the way that UV texture coordinates are generated. Use plannar mapping. Use perspective mapping. Use spherical mapping. Use specular cube mapping. Use Diffuse cube mapping.

enum.name: EndianType
enum.option: The numbers are stored in big endian format, such as those used by PowerPC Mac processors.
The numbers are stored in little endian format, such as those used by Intel and AMD x86 processors.

niftoolsxml.enum: Used by NiPoint3InterpControllers to select which type of color in the controlled object that will be animated. Control the ambient color. Control the diffuse color. Control the specular color. Control the self illumination color.
Used by NiGeometryData to control the volatility of the mesh. While they appear to be flags they behave as an enum. Mutable Mesh Static Mesh Volatile Mesh

enum.name: hkResponseType
enum.option: No collision resolution is performed but listeners are called
Do nothing, ignore all the results.

The NIF file header. 'NetImmerse File Format x.x.x.x' (versions <= 10.0.1.2) or 'Gamebryo File Format x.x.x.x' (versions >= 10.1.0.0), with x.x.x.x the version written out. Ends with a newline character (0x0A).

compound.name: AdditionalDataInfo
compound.add: Type of data in this channel
Number of bytes per element of this channel
Total number of bytes of this channel (num vertices times num bytes per element)
Number of bytes per element in all channels together. Sum of num channel bytes per element over all block infos.

Offset (in bytes) of this channel. Sum of all num channel bytes per element of all preceeding block infos.

compound.name: BSPackedAdditionalDataBlock
compound.add: Total number of bytes (over all channels and all elements, equals num total bytes per element times num vertices).
Number of blocks? Usually equal to one.
Block offsets in the data? Usually equal to zero.
The sum of all of these equal num total bytes per element, so this probably describes how each data element breaks down into smaller chunks (i.e. atoms).
Unsure, but this seems to correspond again to the number of total bytes per element.

niftoolsxml.niobject: The mesh modifier that performs all particle system simulation. The number of simulation steps in this modifier. Links to the simulation steps.
Abstract base class for a single step in the particle system simulation process. It has no seralized data.

enum.name: PSLoopBehavior
enum.option: Key times map such that the first key occurs at the birth of the particle, and times later than the last key get the last key value.
Key times map such that the last key occurs at the death of the particle, and times before the initial key time get the value of the initial key.
Scale the animation to fit the particle lifetime, so that the first key is age zero, and the last key comes at the particle death.
The time is converted to one within the time range represented by the keys, as if the key sequence loops forever in the past and future.
The time is reflection looped, as if the keys played forward then backward the forward then backward etc for all time.

niftoolsxml.niobject:
Encapsulates a floodgate kernel that updates particle size, colors, and rotations.
The number of size animation keys. The particle size keys. The loop behavior for the size keys.
The number of color animation keys. The particle color keys. The loop behavior for the color keys. The number of rotatoin animation keys. The particle rotation keys. The loop behavior for the rotation keys. The the amount of time over which a particle's size is ramped from 0.0 to 1.0 in seconds The the amount of time over which a particle's size is ramped from 1.0 to 0.0 in seconds Specifies the particle generation to which the grow effect should be applied. This is usually generation 0, so that newly created particles will grow. Specifies the particle generation to which the shrink effect should be applied. This is usually the highest supported generation for the particle system, so that particles will shrink immediately before getting killed.
Encapsulates a floodgate kernel that simulates particle forces. The number of forces affecting the particle system. The forces affecting the particle system.
Encapsulates a floodgate kernel that simulates particle colliders. The number of colliders affecting the particle system. The colliders affecting the particle system.
Encapsulates a floodgate kernel that updates mesh particle alignment and transforms. The number of rotation keys. The particle rotation keys. The loop behavior for the rotation keys.
Encapsulates a floodgate kernel that updates particle positions and ages. As indicated by its name, this step should be attached last in the NiPSSimulator mesh modifier.
